instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.3V3_S4: What is 3V3_S4? This is an abbreviation of PP3V3_S4, a 3.3v power rail when the machine is in an S4 state. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board that has been liquid damaged and does not boot. MagSafe does responds (green, then amber). Looking at the board under the scope showed significant damage to pins 3 and 4 on LVDS. Found corrosion on <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> and burn marks on <CAPACITOR>C2385</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C3211</CAPACITOR>. No continuity from <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> pin 18 to <CAPACITOR>C3285</CAPACITOR>.

Started going through power rails and found everything was there until I got 0V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>. So I replaced <CHIP>U3210</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C3285</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C3286</CAPACITOR>, and <CAPACITOR>C3211</CAPACITOR> from a donor board. Jumpered <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> pin 18 to <CAPACITOR>C2385</CAPACITOR>. Still 0V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.

Suggestions on how to proceed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message: Update: Found that <CHIP>U3220</CHIP> also looked pretty shitty. Replaced that from donor board along with <CAPACITOR>C3220</CAPACITOR>. Still 0V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message: check voltage on pin 2,4, and 6 of <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>? Do you have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message:
You are fixing thunderbolt which has nothing to do with power on. 

Is 3v3 present on L7560? If yes check carefully if there are pulses on L7520.

Inspect the usual <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area and the termination resistors in the data lines. Check PPVRTC and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> for corrosion. Check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 for corrosion.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message:
[QUOTE="jgraffis, post: 19835"]check voltage on pin 2,4, and 6 of <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>? Do you have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>?
[/QUOTE]

I unfortunately don't have time to pull <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> to check <CHIP>U8000</CHIP> right now. I know that I have 3.3V on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>...I checked that earlier.

0V on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 19838"]You are fixing thunderbolt which has nothing to do with power on.[/QUOTE]

So even though those IC's are on the <SIGNAL>3V3_S4</SIGNAL> rail that has now power, it was a waste of time working them with regards to solving the no boot situation?


[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 19838"]Is 3v3 present on L7560? If yes check carefully if there are pulses on L7520..[/QUOTE]

3.3V on L7560. Constant 0V on L7520, sampled for about 1 minute.


[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 19838"]Inspect the usual <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area and the termination resistors in the data lines. Check PPVRTC and <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> for corrosion. Check <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 for corrosion.[/QUOTE]

<CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and surrounding components look good. Had looked at those earlier based on some other threads, but checked them over again. Same with <CHIP>U1900</CHIP> and <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

PPVRTC measures 3.3V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 19857"]<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>? Got scope to check 32khz from <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>?[/QUOTE]

<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

<SIGNAL>DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

I do not have an oscilloscope on hand, but may be able to borrow one. Unfortunately buying one is not in the cards at the moment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message: Checked all rails for shorts to GND?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message:
I could have sworn I already checked <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> for short to ground and it wasn't, but right now, it is short to ground. Perhaps it wasn't before I replaced <CHIP>U3210</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3220</CHIP>.

Regardless, do I now inject power into that rail and find the hot spot?

UPDATE: Only shorts to ground with MagSafe attached. I feel like an idiot for having to ask...but if that rail was really shorted to ground, wouldn't it show up short regardless of whether it's to attached to MagSafe?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid Damage No Boot
threads.message: You cannot measure resistance or diode with power applied :(
